channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Extra Unemployment Benefits Kept Some Workers on the Sidelines but Did Not Reduce Overall Employment, Report Says
item.description: Economists are scrambling to figure it out, and yesterday we got a preliminary answer that’s just as nuanced as the question: Extra unemployment insurance (UI) didn’t impact overall job growth, but it did cause a reshuffling of the type of people who were working. The takeawaysIn states that ended extra UI early, hiring for adult workers 25 or older increased the week governors said they were cutting benefits, but returned to typical levels once the benefits actually expired. At the same time, the hiring of teenagers 15–19 jumped in states that didn’t cut the extra benefits.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Checking in on the 'Jeopardy' Hosting Tryouts
item.description: If you answered LeVar Burton you'd be wrong.  Zoom out: Jeopardy!   When Burton made it known he really wanted the gig, fans started a petition that garnered over 250,000 signatures, which caught the eye of the show’s producers. Finding the right host is one of the most crucial decisions facing television execs today. But viewership is down 10% in the post-Trebek world.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 27
item.description: But here’s the funny part—Man Group trades crypto for its clients, because, hey, you can make money. (The Secret Life of Machines) Watch: Fax machines are more clever than you might think.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: China Cracks Down on After-school Tutoring Sector
item.description: The government’s announcement gave the burning-hot industry an ice bath:New Oriental, one of China’s biggest private education companies, has plunged nearly 70% since last Thursday. Why it matters: China’s education technology sector has ballooned to $100 billion, with about 70% of K-12 students enrolled in after-school tutoring programs in major cities.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Tesla Scored Record Profits, Revenue, and Deliveries in Q2
item.description: The company reported a $23 million “impairment” related to its bitcoin holdings. Sales of electric vehicles in the US more than doubled in the first half of 2021 compared to last year.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Covid Vaccine Mandates Gaining Traction
item.description: The Department of Veterans Affairs became the first federal agency to require Covid-19 vaccines for its 115,000 healthcare employees yesterday. American Mandate AssociationEven before those announcements, 57 influential medical groups published a letter urging employers to require Covid vaccines for all healthcare personnel. The White House has no plans to introduce vaccine mandates or passports, so it’s been up to cities, states, and private companies to set vaccine requirements. Covid cases in the city have grown to 800+ per day.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Tesla Scored Record Profits, Revenue, and Deliveries in Q2
item.description: . Sales of electric vehicles in the US more than doubled in the first half of 2021 compared to last year. The company reported a $23 million “impairment” related to its bitcoin holdings.

item.title: China Cracks Down on After-school Tutoring Sector
item.description: The government’s announcement gave the burning-hot industry an ice bath:New Oriental, one of China’s biggest private education companies, has plunged nearly 70% since last Thursday. For all you students who’ve complained about after-school tutoring, the Chinese government agrees with you.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Covid Vaccine Mandates Gaining Traction
item.description: American Mandate AssociationEven before those announcements, 57 influential medical groups published a letter urging employers to require Covid vaccines for all healthcare personnel. Vaccine mandates came in fast and furious yesterday as New York City, California, and the Department of Veterans Affairs introduced a choice for employees: join the Mod(erna) Squad or get a weekly Covid test. The White House has no plans to impose vaccine mandates or passports, so it’s been up to cities, states, and private companies to decide whether to impose vaccine requirements.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Checking in on the 'Jeopardy' Hosting Tryouts
item.description: Zoom out: Jeopardy!   When Burton made it known he really wanted the gig, fans started a petition that garnered over 250,000 signatures, which caught the eye of the show’s producers. The beloved actor LeVar Burton, known for his roles on Star Trek: The Next Generation, Roots, and Reading Rainbow, began his weeklong stint as guest host Jeopardy!
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: July 26
item.description: Economic data: GDP for the second quarter will drop on Thursday. Harry Potter turns 41 on Saturday.  Wanna feel old? So is Lollapalooza. It’s expected to show the US at peak growth—9.7%. Tune in Wednesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 26
item.description: American beach volleyball player Taylor Crabb described what it felt like to train for years to compete in the Olympics only to be quarantined in a Tokyo hotel room. (New York Times)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Assembles Antitrust A-Team
item.description: Facebook and Amazon have asked Khan to step back on any matters involving their companies, while Google could ask the same of Kanter. A favorite of progressives, he has criticized the current antitrust framework for years.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Philip Morris CEO Wants to “Unsmoke the World”
item.description: Big picture: Critics say the public shouldn’t trust cigarette companies to lead a campaign that would ban smoking, especially when they’re still marketing cigarettes in lower income countries where most of the world’s smokers now reside.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Robinhood's Roadshow Previews an IPO Unlike Any Other
item.description: Robinhood execs gave a livestreamed presentation to the public Saturday, ahead of the company’s much-anticipated IPO later this week. Robinhood will price its IPO on Wednesday night and start trading on Thursday. That will allow individual traders to buy stock in the company alongside professionals, and perhaps get ahead of any first-day “pop” in the stock price.   Here’s why:When professional investors buy shares in an IPO, they tend to hold them for a long time.  Companies have historically reserved only 1%–2% of shares for customers, because what Robinhood is doing is risky.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Robinhood's Roadshow Previews an IPO Unlike Any Other
item.description: Robinhood execs gave a livestreamed presentation to the public Saturday, ahead of the company’s much-anticipated IPO later this week. Robinhood will price its IPO on Wednesday night and start trading on Thursday.  But Robinhood isn’t just trying to court professional investors, it’s trying to court you, the regular investor who talks about stocks on your group chat. Here’s why:When professional investors buy shares in an IPO, they tend to hold them for a long time.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Tokyo Olympics Holds Its Surreal Opening Ceremony
item.description: Now comes the fun part: Here’s the master TV schedule for the athletic competitions.  Keith Urban, John Legend, and other singers from across the globe sang “Imagine” together, because we learned nothing from Gal Gadot’s version.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Money Matters: Getting the Right Mix
item.description: How much money should I be investing and saving in cash every month? Keep enough cash to cover three to six months of expenses in a savings account that you can tap in the face of financial hardship. But cash comes first. Perhaps only Elon Musk appears in this newsletter as much as inflation, which is just one reason not to hoard more cash than is necessary.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Make It Work: Why Are You Really Looking For a New Job?
item.description: —Casey from WisconsinHey Casey, if I was asked why I'm looking for a new job and the answer is because I wanted to leave a toxic work environment, I would flip the question and tell the interviewer, "I am looking to be part of a positive and exciting work culture, and I believe that this may be the right place." Ask Kate here. Kate   Something bothering you at work?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Payroll to the People
item.description: Paycom has created Beti, which can further streamline the payroll process by empowering employees to do their own payroll.  And not to get all “ACT NOW” on you, but if you’re waiting until employees ask for employee-driven payroll, it’s already too late. So why keep doing payroll the less-efficient way? Free of FrustrationBy giving employees the tools they need to take control of their payroll processes, you give them the power to prevent frustrating or time-consuming follow-ups if their paycheck is wrong. But now, the thought of a company or brand not having an app seems even more foreign.
item.author: Morning Brew

item.title: Stock Watch: New Olympic Sports
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Icebreakers with...Fashion Icon and Now CEO Stacy London
item.description: The amount that I have learned is like, I didn't know it was possible. Wear what you want. What do I know about running a company? Is there an item of clothing or accessory that you think everyone should have in their closet? I don't think in my entire career there's ever been a time where I was afraid to be vulnerable with my own struggles. But what I really think is that you can wear what you want and get what you want if you understand how style can help you control the narrative of yourself. we just want to talk).  But we've stopped looking for expertise, and we are looking for shared experience. I am. Are you a breakfast person? Both of them have sweet matcha that's not too sweet.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 24
item.description: (The Ringer) Read: The resurgent appeal of Guinness world records. Cooper’s podcast became exclusive to Spotify this week after she signed a $60 million contract with the streamer.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Snap Soars as Social Media Evolves to New Era of Creators and Commerce
item.description: In a previous earnings report, CEO Evan Spiegel said that easing Covid restrictions boosted Story posting and engagement with Snap Map.Strong advertising performance: Snap’s improvements to its ad offerings, paired with more brands putting money into digital ads during the pandemic, has meant advertisers are willing to pay more for placement on its platforms.  The social media company’s stock catapulted nearly 25% the day after reporting its biggest growth quarter in four years. That’s translated into mega revenue growth.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Olympics May Have Been Rescheduled, But The 2020 Logo Doesn’t Know That
item.description: Despite the fact that it is very much the year 2021, all Olympic marketing materials, from the TV ads to the gold medals, are stamped with the “Tokyo 2020” logo. One can only imagine the underground market that would have erupted for “Tokyo 2020” merch. Like your old high school friend who constantly brings up his state football championship, the Tokyo Olympics are living in the past. A decision to keep the original branding was made last March, when Japan and the International Olympic Committee agreed to postpone the Summer games for the first time in history.  The real reason Tokyo 2020 didn’t become Tokyo 2021 is because a change would have been supremely expensive.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Boston Beer, Maker of Truly Hard Seltzer, Says Hard Seltzer Party Is Over
item.description: Shares in Boston Beer, the company that makes Truly hard seltzer, collapsed 27% yesterday after it warned the seltzer party was over.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: July 23
item.description: Quote: “I think we will effectively transition from people seeing us as primarily being a social media company to being a metaverse company.” (Object of Sound)
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Startup Announces Breakthrough Technology for Energy Storage
item.description: Form’s batteries may be key to achieving President Biden’s goal of a carbon-free power grid in the US by 2035. Form Energy, a startup backed by Bill Gates and Jeff Bezos, might have cracked the code: batteries made from iron that can hold electricity for days or even weeks.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: The Housing Market Frenzy May Have Peaked
item.description: Yes, the US median house price did hit a record high of $363,300 last month, up 22.9% from a year earlier. Before you offer $100k over asking price on a new home, you should hear this: The boiling US housing market took a refreshing dip in the pool in June.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: California Sues Gaming Company Activision Blizzard
item.description: California legislators sued video game developer Activision Blizzard yesterday, citing its “pervasive ‘frat boy’ culture” and mistreatment of women employees. The suit details that one female employee died by suicide on a corporate trip after nude photos were leaked and shared among male colleagues who had previously harassed her. Bottom line: The lawsuit against Activision Blizzard shows that the #MeToo movement is still reaching its crescendo in the video game industry.  Ubisoft (Assassin’s Creed, Far Cry) was accused of rampant sexism and racism last summer. Denial on all fronts. Activision’s response?
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: The Business Olympiad
item.description: Work Softwarathon  Toby Howell This is by far the most organized event in the Olympiad which makes it one of the more intriguing. 10 Events, 90 participants, and everything to play for, the Business Olympiad will see the best in the biz world come together to compete for a place on the podium. and the questions the first inaugural Business Olympiad will endeavor to answer. Business Flameouts  Toby Howell This event bravely asks the question: who is the best at being the worst?   Fictional Business Freestyle Toby Howell Movies give us laughs, cries, and huge fictional megacorporations. Synchronized Businessing  Toby Howell It's hard to go at it alone in the business world.  Over the next two weeks, Morning Brew readers will have the opportunity to participate in a business competition unlike any other. They might make your skin crawl, but only one email cliche can take home the gold. Then, a second round of polls will be held to determine who stands atop the podium. Lots of mico-matchups to watch in this one from the battle of the inboxes with Outlook and Gmail, to the business communication faceoff between Slack and Teams.  Font Medley Relay Toby Howell Even if you think you don’t have an opinion on the best fonts, you do.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: US Housing Market Frenzy May Have Peaked
item.description: Before you offer $100k over asking price on a new home, you should hear this: The boiling US housing market took a refreshing dip in the pool in June. More owners listed their homes last month after they saw home seekers offering things like crypto in order to secure the deed.
item.author: Sherry Qin
